prompt: Rewrite this paragraph to be calmer and more precise: 'Big tech moves fast and breaks things, ruining everything.'
Edit this sentence to remove hedging while keeping nuance: 'Exercise might possibly help mood a little.'
Turn these notes into a clear three-step plan for starting a home garden this spring.
Convert a rambling status update into bullet points with actions, owners, and due dates.
Write a concise, neutral abstract of a news story about public transit funding without taking sides.
Restructure this claim into claim → evidence → next steps: 'Walking meetings boost creativity; small study; try twice weekly.'
Explain CRISPR in plain language for a curious 12-year-old using short, direct sentences.
Rewrite this feedback to be specific and supportive: 'Your report was confusing.'
Make this sentence less emotional and more precise: 'The app is super slow and totally useless.'
Write a succinct overview of how vaccines work, avoiding jargon and keeping sentences under 20 words.
Provide a structured explanation (definition, example, limitation) of opportunity cost for a first-time learner.
Turn this idea into a one-paragraph proposal with a clear ask: start a weekly team demo day.
Condense three paragraphs about climate feedback loops into a single balanced paragraph.
Rewrite to remove filler while keeping the meaning: 'I was thinking that maybe we could possibly meet next week?'
Convert this messy brainstorm into a simple weekly guitar practice plan.
Draft a courteous, direct email asking for a project status update.
Make this claim less absolute and more nuanced: 'Remote work is always better.'
Create a 'what, why, how' explainer for two-factor authentication for a non-technical friend.
Rephrase this to be neutral and concise: 'The city’s plan is obviously a disaster for commuters.'
Outline a brief interview prep checklist: company research, practice stories, logistics.
Summarize the core idea of the Lindy effect in two clear sentences for a general audience.
Transform notes into a clear roadmap to learn Python in four weeks with small projects.
Edit this claim to include a caveat and source cue: 'Coffee extends lifespan.'
Write a calm, precise note explaining why a refund request was denied and what to try next.
Refactor a paragraph about budgeting into bullet points that are specific and measurable.
Revise this product feedback to be constructive and specific instead of vague: 'Your service is bad.'
Explain Bayesian thinking in accessible language with one concrete example.
Create a neutral paragraph summarizing both support and criticism of electric scooters in cities.
Clarify this instruction for assembling a simple shelf using short steps and plain language.
Rewrite this caption to be informative instead of sensational: 'Shocking discovery in space!'
Turn this note into action items: 'Kitchen is messy; supplies low; guests arrive Friday.'
Edit to avoid hype and keep facts first: 'Our startup is the best ever!'
Write a short, even-toned note explaining why software updates matter to someone who delays them.
Summarize a book’s key idea in one sentence, then list two practical takeaways.
Provide a 'claim, evidence, counterpoint' outline on whether breakfast improves focus.
Condense a long explanation of photosynthesis into a clear two-sentence overview.
Rewrite a meeting invite to be shorter, clearer, and include agenda and outcomes.
Polish instructions for resetting a router so they are easy for a non-expert to follow.
Convert a messy travel packing list into categories with must-haves and nice-to-haves.
Draft a neutral summary explaining what a replication crisis is and why replication matters.
